ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Understanding of British culture, literature and social movements specifically in the post-war period
I learned how to read, think, and talk about contemporary British literature, theater, and film.
I learned a lot about British history in the 20th century and how literature allows us to explore and understand that history.

This is an absolutely unbelievable class. I learned to trace the history of a nation via its narratives without being constrained to a particular format - we covered poems, plays and novels alike. They were written by a diverse array of authors too. I look at contemporary Britain in a totally new light now
We read plays and novels and watched movies produced in post-WW2 Britain, and got a sense of the energy of the time, especially relating to class, race, gender, and empire.
I got a better view of contemporary British history and literature.

I gained an understanding of the preoccupations of British authors and their literature, from the mid-20th century onward. This includes a knowledge of the historical and political contexts surrounding these works, as well as the influence of burgeoning media forms on more "traditional" ones.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strength is that the professor is very intelligent, communicative, and thoughtful. The workload was not high but I came out of the class feeling like I had learned something about a subject that I had previously known very little about. The use of movies (however sparingly) was also productive. The main weakness is the he does not invest very much in individual students. I didn't find a mentor or even someone who seemed to take any particular interest in me or my thoughts as an intellectual. Regardless, an enriching class. Just don't expect a hands-on experience.

Strengths - interesting material, cool professor
Weaknesses - none
Really great course. I learned so much from our weekly discussions and also from the papers I wrote.

It is honestly hard to improve it. Students are kept engaged both by discussions with each other/Prof. Phillips as well as by the requirement to present one text each over the course of the semester. I also liked that there weren't unnecessary papers during the semester - only one 2-pager to take stock of how we felt about the material. I'm excited for anyone who gets to take this in person.

The syllabus was wonderfully constructed, and Professor Phillipss insights about each work were thought-provoking and illuminating. I wish we had more feedback on our written work throughout the semester, but then again, the major assignment was our end of term final paper.

I didn't always feel like there was enough time allocated for students to discuss the works. I would have rather spent less time on the student introducing the work and more time on close reading and interpretation. Sometimes, it felt like Prof Phillips was trying to steer us towards his interpretation of the works, rather than facilitate open-ended discussion.
I loved the course! very engaging material and peers! I have no complaints.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It worked fine.
Wish there could've been a way to get to know my classmates better - maybe a weekly blog post on Canvas?

Honestly, even over Zoom, the class discussion was very engaging. I liked that one or two students presented on the author and the work at the beginning of the session, because it was a good way to ease into discussion.
It was pretty seamless given the circumstances. No unnecessary gimmicky use of technology was a definite strength.
Though this seminar was over Zoom, I was completely engaged throughout the semester. Professor Phillips guided class discussion very well.

I think the biggest disadvantage to not having in-person classes is the inability to form relationships with other students. I think the nature of online classes makes informal interaction impossible. I miss that a lot.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes - very informative course.
Yes! You will get what you put into it and Prof. Phillips is amazing. Reading contemporary works is so important!

Would absolutely recommend this class to anyone interested in Anglophone literature. The works we read were super carefully chosen and were really interesting, and the discussion was always fun. Professor Phillips is brilliant and a really good teacher. Could not recommend more highly! One of my favorite classes I've taken at Yale.

Highly recommended. That is all I can say. If you are at all interested in postcolonial writing, good plays, the Empire or even learning about Britain for the first time with a unique lens, then this is for you.
Absolutely! A course I looked forward to every week.
I loved the syllabus; I didn't vibe with the seminar format. I didn't feel like this class pushed or expanded my beliefs in many ways.
Yes! Professor Phillips is an amazing teacher with a distinct point of view, making the class extremely engaging and informative.

Yes! I enjoyed every work on the syllabus. Class discussions were natural, and because the syllabus was interesting, there weren't too many lags or pauses in discussion. It was easy to become invested in the histories and books the class explored.
